description:
The application is really useful and makes comparing and selective merging a joy.


I give full marks though i had sme grief installing it with "Gonome Software"

I ended up installing from the fedora repo with "dnf install meld" not then flatpak version, because it's easier to launch from command line (to lanch flatpak app you'd have to invoke "flatpak run org.gnome.Meld fileA fileB".

Not sure why Gnome Software doesn't list the repository version just the flatpak one, and it installed an older version as well which had to pull down 600MB's worth of "fedora 32 runtime", a bit of a waste of time
summary: It's a great graphical compare/merge tool

description: Easy to use, does what I need. I still like Araxis Merge better, but this is a fair substitute for Linux.
Never disappoints me. May throw some errors on the terminal but looks graphically smooth and easy to use.

What the heck is wrong with programmers that don't care about the basic functionality of their software? For instance this app, which, on a dark theme, doesn't show clearly the differences between files, a feature that is elementary in this case. Oh, it's the main and only feature! The problem is that the changes are shown in a color almost identical to that of the line that contains them.
Another thumb down: why is the app going crazy (using the disk drive and the CPU like there is no tomorrow) if I try to compare two simple text files (a few bytes each) that aren't in ~/Documents? If I put them in ~, or some location other than ~/Documents, the app loses its temper.
summary: The app's motto: I don't care

I can still click on a file, I just cannot read the fle name

I really liked the feature that you can paste text instead of only selecting a file. Some other programs force you to use only file, this allows you to paste from clipboard. I wish there are more templates, different and variety. But overall, I liked it.
Simple, efficient,

description: A+ and it has a dark scheme!

I use Meld as my go-to diff tool for everything python, javascript, markdown, adoc, git (git config set difftool). Love the way it highlights individual words that are different. And the hotkeys that let you quickly review and merge or ignore changes. Have yet to master the 3-way merge though.

A good diff tool that shows line by line the differences. You can even move changes to the diff files. What I like is the directory diff, works great on my development environment. I would give it 5 stars but sometimes MELD crashes.
It has proven very handy for comparing versions of files on different source drives. The ability to compare files, directories, and even versions of source files against the repository is great.
summary: This is a great comparator tool. Nicely done

description: This app only compares a directory STRUCTURE or individual files. It does that fine, I guess, but that's extremely limiting for my needs. If you moved a bunch of files around and want to see if there are any you missed or if you have two sets of records with differing structures, this app is of no use. It won't tell you, for example, if /DirectoryX/SubDirectoryY/FileA.XXX has an identical in /Other1/SubOther2.
thanks for great app
Easy to use, and works everytime to compare and merge files.
summary: Easy to use, and works everytime to compare and merge files

description: This version open in full screen and don´t allow to resize

Great software but fails to compare individual files... at least as of Ubuntu falvours 22.04. Folder comparison still works, however. It seems there is very little software to perform binary compares for linux (at least that I've found) and I've yet to see anyone explain how to binary compare on the command line in a way that actually works and is actually binary. This app is the only thing standing bewteen me knowing my 8TB of files have copied properly and oblivion. Needs fixing!

Have tried a number of apps designed / developed by Gnome and ignored the 1 STAR reviews - I must say now I understand the reason!

Truth is, Gnome developers are bored or tired of doing their jobs! Simple as that!

Just look at their king of their projects - > Gnome DE!

Each and every release, they cut a number of features - depending on 3rd party developers to come up with some extensions!

But even then, the next DE breaks bunch - extension develoeprs fix them - REPEAT!

I do folder comparisons as well as write programs, and I also do maintenance.
Meld highlights the changes in the programs and shows me what was inserted
and removed. I can update one source with the other using lines, or full replacements. I 
I can handle directories in a similar manner.

A1 Program 10/10
